section.title: Introduction
section.para: VE-Launcher is a quick, easy way to launch any configuration of VE-Suite. It helps you save your configuration, choose which programs to run, and launch them without entering text commands. Even with all of the options and configurations available, choosing the one you need can still take some work. Here, we explain how to use the Launcher and provide an example setup.

section.title: Starting the Launcher
section.para: On the Windows install, VE-Launcher is an executable. Double-click on it to start.

On the Unix-based install, VE-Launcher is a python program. Go into VE-Suite's /bin directory and run velauncher.py. Specifically, from the command line, you can enter the /bin directory and type "python velauncher.py" to run the launcher.

For both Windows and Unix-based development versions, VE-Launcher is a python program, just like with the Unix-based install. Run it in the same way as the Unix-based install. In dev mode, VE-Launcher does not require you to set dependencies and it looks for stereo desktop config files in their build location, not their install location.

Preset Environmental Variables: Certain values, such as the VPR_DEBUG_LEVEL, can be automatically passed into VE-Launcher from the environment when VE-Launcher starts. If they are set in the environment, they overwrite the values saved from previous VE-Launcher start. These variables include:

listitem.para: VE_DEPS_DIR (Dependencies Directory - Windows only)
This is the base directory in which the VE-Suite dependencies installer places the associated files during a Windows install.
VJ_BASE_DIR (VR Juggler Directory - Unix only)
This is the base directory in which VRJuggler is installed during a Unix install.
VE_WORKING_DIR (Working Directory)
This is the location of a desired application
TAO_MACHINE (TAO Machine)

This is the computer in which the VE-CE is being run. In desktop mode this is set to the local machine and cannot connect to another computer. In other modes (i.e., cluster mode), the TAO_MACHINE is run on a single computer and the other nodes communicate with this computer.
TAO_PORT (TAO Port)
This is the port number on the TAO_Machine through which the communication is being passed.
OSGNOTIFYLEVEL (OSG Debug Level)
This is a numeric value that assigns how much debug output is displayed for OpenSceneGraph (the scene graph that VE_Xplorer uses).
VPR_DEBUG_ENABLE (VPR Debug)
This is a YES/NO value that assigns how much debug output is displayed for VR Juggler.
VPR_DEBUG_NFY_LEVEL (VPR Debug Level)
This is a YES/NO value that assigns how much debug output is displayed for VR Juggler.

section.title: Setting the Launcher's Dependencies
section.para: Before VE-Suite can be run, VE-Launcher must be pointed to its dependencies. How this should be done depends on whether VE-Suite is being run on a Windows or a Unix-based system. Pointing to the dependencies is bypassed completely in Dev mode; VE-Launcher assumes the environmental variables have been set.

Windows: VE-Launcher needs to find the VE-Suite Dependencies directory that was installed along with VE-Suite. The first time the Launcher is started, the user is prompted to choose the Dependencies directory for it. This should be named VE_Suite.#.#_Dependencies. If the Dependencies directory needs to be changed later, it can be done from the Options->Choose Dependencies menu in VE-Launcher.

Unix: VE-Launcher supports dependencies spread across multiple directories. The first time the Launcher is started, it will ask you to choose its Dependencies' directories. Add each dependency's directory to the list.
The only exception is VR-Juggler's dependency directory. Since it sets multiple variables, it needs to be chosen separately from the other dependencies.
If the Dependencies directory needs to be changed later, it can be done from the Options->Choose Dependencies menu in VE-Launcher.
Dev Mode: VE-Launcher does not require dependencies in Dev mode; it assumes that the necessary environmental variables have already been set.
Once the dependencies have been selected, VE-Launcher's main window displays.

section.title: The Basics
section.para: VE-Launcher's main window provides the basic choices that need to be made before running VE-Suite. Here is a breakdown of what can be done from here:

listitem.para: Working Directory: Can either type in the directory with the files you want to load, or browse the file system with the button.
Computation Engine (CE) Name and Port: Enter the computer and port you want to connect to.
Launch Mode: Select which mode you would like to launch VE-Suite in. You have six options:
Desktop mode launches Conductor, Name Server, and Xplorer on your machine in Desktop mode.
Tablet mode launches Conductor. It is designed for use on tablets.
Computation mode launches the Name Server. It is designed for use on computational engines.
Visualization mode launches Xplorer. It is designed for viewing projects. It uses Custom's settings to choose VR Juggler's configuration and which type of Xplorer to run.

Shell mode lets the user work in a new shell with the VE-Suite environment set up. If you choose to launch in Shell mode, it will ask you whether you want to set up this shell for VE-Builder. If you do, it will add the VE-Builder directory you choose to the path. On Windows, launching Shell creates the shell in a window; simply close it to exit. On Unix, launching Shell makes the shell a child of your current terminal; type in "exit" to return to your original shell.
Custom mode lets the user choose their own settings.

section.para: The settings for every mode can be viewed and changed by clicking the Mode Settings button. Once you finish choosing the settings, click Launch VE-Suite to close VE-Launcher and start VE-Suite.

section.title: Launcher Menus
section.para: The launcher's main window has a menu bar with the following menus:

listitem.para: File menu:
Open...: Pick a .ves or script shell file for launch.
Open Recent File: Pick a recently-launched .ves or script shell file for launch.

para.emphasis: Preferences: Allows the user to set a default working directory rather than using the directory that was in use during the last session.

listitem.para: Close File: Remove any .ves or script shell files from the launch.
Quit: Quit VE-Launcher.
Configurations menu:
Load: Load a previously saved VE-Launcher configuration. VE-Launcher configurations store information such as Mode settings, Xplorer configurations, and cluster settings.
Save: Save the current VE-Launcher configuration.
Delete: Delete a previously saved VE-Launcher configuration.
Options menu:
Choose Dependencies: Change the location of Dependencies based on where the user has installed them.
Choose Builder Folder: Change the Builder directory (Windows only).

para.emphasis: Set Debug Levels: Display the varying amounts of debug output for VRJuggler and OpenSceneGraph.

listitem.para: Auto-Launch Passed Files: If checked, files passed as arguments to VE-Launcher are instantly launched. If unchecked, files passed as arguments are opened in VE-Launcher for the user to manually launch.
Cluster Wait Times: Customize the time VE-Suite waits between starting the master node and its slaves, and the time VE-Suite waits between starting individual slaves.
Help menu

section.title: Mode Settings
section.para: Use the Mode Settings window to view and change settings. The Desktop, Tablet, and Computation modes only let you view their settings; Visualization mode lets you change the Xplorer Mode and cluster computers; Custom mode lets you change every setting. Choices are faded out if they cannot be changed, or if changing them would not do anything. For example, you cannot choose which Xplorer Mode to run if you are not running Xplorer.
Options that can be set include:

listitem.para: Which VR Juggler configuration to use from the pulldown list. You can edit the list by clicking Edit Configuration List. The List will be discussed in more detail below.
Which programs to run. You can choose to run Name Server, Conductor, and Xplorer. You must select at least one of them or VE-Suite will not launch.
Whether to run Conductor and Xplorer in Desktop Mode. This checkbox is disabled if you are not launching either of them.
Which mode to run Xplorer in. You can choose between non-cluster mode (single computer) or cluster mode. This radio list is disabled if you are not launching Xplorer.

section.para: VE-Suite has multiple configuration files available. To help you keep track of them, VE-Launcher keeps a list of the configuration files you use where you can add, rename, and delete list entries. The path to the currently selected entry is listed below, so you can tell which name stands for which file.
When you add a new configuration to the list, its initial name is its file name. It should be renamed to something more descriptive.

section.title: UNIX Clusters
section.para: VE-Launcher can run VE-Suite across a cluster from one computer. To use the cluster functions of VE-Launcher on Unix, the cluster must satisfy these requirements:

listitem.para: The path to VE-Suite, its dependencies, and the working directory are the same on every cluster node.
VE-Launcher's user has permission to ssh to each node.
The user has manually sshed into each node and authenticated its host.

section.para: The last requirement needs some explanation. The first time you ssh into an unknown host, you need to manually authenticate its name. If it is not authenticated and VE-Launcher tries to connect to it, it will hang the program. Therefore, you must manually ssh into each node on the cluster (including your current computer) and authenticate it before you can start the cluster using VE-Launcher. You must use the exact name you will use in VE-Launcher; ssh treats partially qualified (e.g., francis) and fully qualified (e.g., francis.iastate.edu) names as separate users. Once you authenticate the other nodes, the authentication stays in your user profile permanently.
Once you have authenticated all nodes, you can run the cluster from VE-Launcher:

listitem.para: If you are running NameServer and Conductor on a certain node, open VE-Launcher from that node. (VE-Launcher runs NameServer and Conductor from the current computer.)
Set your settings and select the Cluster Xplorer mode. The Cluster Settings button will then be enabled.
Click Cluster Settings. A window will pop up showing the master and slaves listed. Put the master's name in, add each slave's name to the list, then click OK.
You can also pass extra variables to the cluster computers. Click on the Pass Extra Vars, list the extra variables you want to pass, then click OK.
Launch VE-Suite by clicking Launch. The cluster computers will start up VE-Suite.

section.para: NOTE: There is a slight delay between each node launched because simultaneous launching causes erratic behavior in clusters. The delay can be changed through the Options->Cluster Wait Times menu. If you encounter problems with sync or unconnected nodes using VE-Launcher, try lengthening the delays. If launching the cluster is taking too long, try shortening them.

section.title: Windows Clusters
section.para: VE-Launcher can start VE-Suite across a Windows cluster through PsExec.
To use the cluster functions of VE-Launcher on Windows, your cluster must satisfy these requirements:

listitem.para: The path to VE-Suite, its dependencies, and the working directory are the same on every cluster node.
PsExec is installed on the computer you are running VE-Launcher on.

section.para: To launch the cluster:

listitem.para: If you are running NameServer and Conductor on a certain computer, open VE-Launcher from that computer. (VE-Launcher runs NameServer and Conductor from the current computer.)
Set your settings and select the Cluster Xplorer mode. The Cluster Settings button will then be enabled.
Click Cluster Settings. A window will pop up showing the master and slaves listed, plus an optional username field. Put the master's name in, then add each slave's name to the list.

Some clusters might require you to connect as a certain user; if so, just enter your username into the User Name field. The username's domain may need to be included as well, depending on your cluster's setup. If you pass your username, you will have to manually enter your password in each Psexec window as it launches; VE-Launcher doesn't send passwords for security reasons.
You can also pass extra variables to the cluster computers. Click on the Pass Extra Vars and list the extra variables you want to pass, then click OK.
Launch VE-Suite by clicking Launch. The cluster computers will start up VE-Suite.

section.para: NOTE: There is a slight delay between each node launched because simultaneous launching can cause erratic behavior in the cluster. The delay can be changed through the Options->Cluster Wait Times menu. If you encounter problems with sync or unconnected nodes using VE-Launcher, try lengthening the delays. If it's taking too long to launch the cluster, try shortening them.

The cluster template: If your cluster needs extra code to launch (for example, a net use command to set up a remote drive), you can enter the code into the clusterTemplate.txt file. Any terminal code in the clusterTemplate.txt file will run on the cluster's other computers before Xplorer is launched. Please read the comments in clusterTemplate.txt for more details.

section.title: VE-Launcher Command Line Arguments
section.para: Once VE-Launcher is set up, you can quickly start up VE-Suite by passing arguments from the command line. Some arguments pass values to VE-Launcher; others bypass VE-Launcher completely and auto-launch VE-Suite. (Arguments that auto-launch VE-Suite use the previously saved settings for any fields they do not change.)

listitem.para: (file): Passes a .ves file or shell script named (file) to VE-Launcher. Auto-launches VE-Suite if Auto-Launch Passed Files has been selected in VE-Launcher; otherwise VE-Launcher is started with the file loaded.
-q, --quick: Auto-launches VE-Suite with its most recent settings.
-g <config>, --config=<config>: Loads the VE-Launcher configuration named <config>.
-d, --dev: Starts VE-Launcher in Development mode.
-w <dir>, --dir=<dir>: Auto-launches VE-Suite with the working directory set to <dir>.
-t <name>, --taomachine=<name>: Auto-launches VE-Suite with TAOMACHINE set to <name>.
-p <port>, --port=<port>: Auto-launches VE-Suite with PORT set to <port>.
-j <file>, --jconf=<file>: Auto-launches VE-Suite using <file> as VE-Xplorer's Juggler configuration.
-l <boolean>, --cluster=<boolean>: If <boolean>==True, auto-launches VE-Suite in cluster mode. If <boolean>==False, auto-launches VE-Suite in non-cluster mode.
-b, --debug: Auto-launches VE-Suite and debugs the launch.

Program Arguments: Program arguments set certain parts of VE-Suite to run. They auto-launch VE-Suite, running the programs specified. Note that only the programs specified in the arguments are run; if you just pass '-x -n', for example, only Xplorer and the Computational Engine will run, even if the default settings usually run Conductor as well.
The program arguments are:
-n, --nameserver: Runs the Computational Engine.
-c, --conductor: Runs VE-Conductor.
-x, --xplorer Runs VE-Xplorer
-s, --shell: Runs a shell with VE-Suite's environment set.

section.title: Example
section.para: John Doe wants to set up VE-Suite to look at a virtual power plant design. He needs to start it in Visualization mode, using the VR Juggler configuration "standalone". It also has to connect to computer kiwi on port 1239.
When he starts VE-Launcher, he sees this:
First he types the path to the plant design data folder in the Working Directory field. (He could also use the Choose Working Directory button to find it.)

He needs to change the computational engine (CE) name, but he can't because the Launcher is currently in Desktop mode, which automatically sets the CE name to "localhost". To unlock the CE name, he switches to Visualization mode. (Any mode besides Desktop will let you change the CE name.)
Switching modes unlocks the CE name and sets it to the last user-inputted value. Now John can change the CE name and port.
To finish setting up the Launcher, John must change the mode's settings. He clicks the Mode Settings button to bring up the Settings window.

Visualization mode sets most of the options, and the Non-Cluster Xplorer mode is already selected. That leaves changing the Xplorer configuration. However, the configuration he needs is not on the list yet. John clicks Edit Configuration List.
Because it is not on the list, he adds it.
It is automatically added to the list with the name "standalone". John renames it "Plant Design" so he can remember which project it is for.

Now that he is done editing the list, John exits the Xplorer Configuration window. Because Plant Design was selected when he left, it is automatically set as his current configuration file. With everything set as he wanted, John can now click Launch VE-Suite to look at the design.
